awd_titl_txt: Type I: Greensboro I-Corps Training Site
awd_abstract_narration:
This project, from the University of North Carolina at Greensboro, creates an I-Corps Site. 

NSF Innovation Corps (I-Corps) Sites are NSF-funded entities established at universities whose purpose is to nurture and support multiple, local teams to transition their technology concepts into the marketplace. Sites provide infrastructure, advice, resources, networking opportunities, training and modest funding to enable groups to transition their work into the marketplace or into becoming I-Corps Team applicants. I-Corps Sites also strengthen innovation locally and regionally and contribute to the National Innovation Network of mentors, researchers, entrepreneurs and investors.

The Greensboro I-Corps Training Site (GRIT) is a collaboration between the geographically adjacent University of North Carolina at Greensboro (UNCG-lead institution) and North Carolina Agriculture and Technical State University (N.C. A&T). Expanding on the existing entrepreneurship missions at the two universities, the GRIT facilitates the commercialization of innovative ideas and research at both institutions, as well as nearby institutions of higher education and the surrounding communities. UNCG's North Carolina Entrepreneurship Center (NCEC) recruits teams from both schools, provides training and measures outcomes of the program. The program focuses on science, technology, engineering, and mathematics and also looks to provide training to any innovation that offers scalable solutions to societal problems.

This Site focuses on inclusion of diverse perspectives from underrepresented cohorts by expanding the training of the commercialization process to populations often underrepresented in entrepreneurship. Expanding training opportunities to women, minorities, people with disabilities, military veterans, and new immigrants fosters greater inclusion. UNCG, a former women's college and a Minority Serving Institution (MSI), and N.C. A&T, the nation's largest Historically Black College and University (HBCU), provide a large ideal population of diverse potential entrepreneurs. 

The Greensboro area is transforming its economic identity by embracing entrepreneurial activities and inclusiveness of underrepresented populations through establishment and support of community accelerators and programs that will help advance this new growth. The GRIT helps support local economic development collaborations between universities, industry, and local government by providing a new source of trained entrepreneurs and technologies, ultimately directly benefiting the community.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: UNIVERSITY OF NORTH CAROLINA AT GREENSBORO

por.por_cntn:
The Greensboro I-Corps Site program had numerous overall goals:

1. Provide training to help propel teams to have meaningful experiences in customer discovery, business model development and value proposition, focusing their activities in order to get to go or no-go decisions in a shorter amount of time.

2. Provide a methodology for students and faculty to work with external resources and stakeholders on early business ideas, providing growth opportunities for the individuals and the universities through expanded partnerships and networking.

3. Achieve diversity of thought and representation from underrepresented and under connected populations by expanding training opportunities to women, minorities, people with disabilities, military veterans, and new immigrants to foster greater inclusion.

4. Support regional economic development collaborations between universities, industry, and local government by providing a new source of trained LLP entrepreneurs and technologies, ultimately directly benefiting the community.

5. Increased commercialization activity at both Universities, increasing the number of invention disclosures, patent application-ready and eligible technologies, granted patents, industry partnerships, increased funding from government and non-government entities (including SBIR/STTR), increase number of start-up companies formed, increase number of student participants getting hired, and development of new research pathways.

Outcomes

The Greensboro NSF I-Corps Program fulfilled its mission of fostering innovation and entrepreneurship by hosting 18 Cohorts consisting of 144 total teams made up of 311 participants. 

The program was able to operate within a 100% virtual environment that was initiated during the COVID-19 pandemic and continued through the end of the funding period. This adaptability demonstrated the program's commitment to delivering its objectives even in challenging circumstances. 

One of the program's key goals was to ensure inclusive participation. This objective was met successfully, and the diverse representation of team academic programs persisted, reaffirming the program's belief that innovation thrives across various disciplines on campus.

The cumulative totals achieved over the entire funding period further underscored the program's impact on fostering diversity and inclusion in entrepreneurship:

  • Teams led by minorities: 97
  • Teams led by women: 87
  • Teams that participated in the National I-Corps: 10
  • Start-ups initiated: 45

The comprehensive metrics for the entire funding period provide a holistic view of the program's achievements:

  • Cohorts: 18
  • Teams: 144
  • Participants: 311
  • National I-Corps Teams: 10
  • Patents: 10
  • Licensing Agreements: 2
  • Start-Ups: 45
  • Funds Raised: $2,766,005

These metrics not only showcase the scale of the program but also highlight its tangible contributions to the entrepreneurial landscape, including the creation of start-ups and the significant funds raised by participating teams.

The success of the program is not merely measured in quantitative terms but is also reflected in the qualitative impact on participants. According to survey results, 100% of teams that completed the program acknowledged that I-Corps significantly increased their knowledge of crucial entrepreneurial elements, including the business model canvas, customer discovery, and lean launchpad. This positive feedback reinforces the program's effectiveness in providing valuable skills and insights to its participants.

To extend the impact beyond the program's immediate participants, Launch UNCG has implemented various initiatives. Launch UNCG workshops have been conducted for diverse groups, both on and off-campus, including students, government employees, and professional development programs. This comprehensive approach ensures that the knowledge and skills imparted by the program have a broader reach and contribute to the overall entrepreneurial ecosystem. Professional development has also been seamlessly integrated into one-on-one consultations provided by Launch UNCG staff to early-stage entrepreneurs each year. 

Additionally, Launch UNCG has forged a strategic partnership with Launch GSO, a program offered through the Greensboro Chamber of Commerce. This collaboration provides supplemental entrepreneurial programming to I-Corps teams, further enriching their entrepreneurial journey and expanding their network of resources.

Furthermore, Launch UNCG actively participates in quarterly region-wide Triad Entrepreneurship Ecosystem Meetings. This involvement provides an opportunity to share outcomes, exchange ideas, and collaborate with stakeholders in the broader entrepreneurial ecosystem. 

The annual North Carolina State-wide NSF I-Corps Site Summit served as another valuable platform for the program to share information and experiences with colleagues across the state involved in similar programs. This collaborative approach ensures that best practices are shared, and lessons learned are disseminated, contributing to the continuous improvement of entrepreneurial support initiatives statewide.

In summary, the Greensboro NSF I-Corps Program has not only met its goals of inclusive participation and diverse representation but has also demonstrated adaptability and success in a virtual environment. The program's commitment to providing valuable skills and knowledge is evident in both quantitative metrics and qualitative feedback from participants. The comprehensive approach to professional development, partnerships with external programs, and active participation in regional and state-wide meetings underscore the program's dedication to contributing to the broader entrepreneurial ecosystem. The dissemination of outcomes through various channels ensures that the impact of the program is widely recognized and celebrated, further solidifying its role as a catalyst for innovation and entrepreneurship.

 

 


Last Modified: 01/29/2024
Modified by: David L Wyrick
